abstract.p: After a period of consultation, it has been decided that the Revenue should be empowered to issue legally-binding rulings in favour of taxpayers only where the relevant transaction has already taken place. This paper considers the reasons for having binding rulings, and argues that those reasons justify implementing pre- as well as post-transaction rulings. Additionally, it is contended that many of the more detailed aspects of the proposal warrant reconsideration in light of those underlying rationales.

I use the terms 'advance rulings' and 'binding rulings' interchangeably in this paper.

The Commissioner of Inland Revenue (New Zealand) is enabled by the Tax Administration Amendment Act 1995 (ss. 91A to 911) to make binding rulings on how taxation laws apply to any person(s) or arrangement. The legislation was implemented in two stages: (a) from 1 April 1995, enabling all rulings except private rulings on arrangements entered into before the date on which the Commissioner received the application for the ruling and (b) from 1 April 1996, for private rulings on arrangements entered into before the date on which the Commissioner received the application for the ruling.
